results.title: Get Ready for the ‘Ring of Fire’ Solar Eclipse This Saturday
results.abstract: The moon will slip in front of the sun, leaving a fiery orange rim in the sky that will be visible for just a few minutes.

media.caption: An annular eclipse in Arizona in 2012.

results.title: Trump’s Remarks on Hezbollah and Netanyahu Prompt Bipartisan Outcry

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump weighed in on the attacks during a speech on Wednesday to his supporters in West Palm Beach, Fla.

results.title: Seeking a Moral Compass in Gaza’s War
results.abstract: The U.S. bungled its response to 9/11. Let’s hope Israel moves forward with greater wisdom.

media.caption: The funeral for May Naim, 24, who was killed in a Hamas terrorist attack in Israel.

results.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Lisa Lerer
results.title: Israeli Billboards Thanking the U.S. Have a New Face on Them: Biden’s
results.abstract: After Donald J. Trump bound himself tightly to the Israeli right, and President Biden approached the divided nation gingerly, a warm presidential embrace has eased years of tension.

media.caption: President Biden’s speech condemning the “evil” perpetrated by Hamas that killed more than 1,200 Israelis as well as his other shows of support for Israel have met a warm reception from some of his political opponents.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Television;Actors and Actresses;Nineteen Hundred Sixties;Science Fiction;Goddard, Mark (1936-2023)
results.title: Mark Goddard, a Star of the ’60s Series ‘Lost in Space,’ Dies at 87
results.abstract: For three seasons, he and a family of five, a wily (and annoying) saboteur and a talking robot were marooned on a distant planet in the far-off future: 1997.

media.caption: Mark Goddard as Maj. Don West on “Lost in Space,” which was seen on CBS from 1965 to 1968. He was theoretically the show’s leading man, but its tone shifted after the first season and it became more comedy than adventure.

results.adx_keywords: Philanthropy;Deaths (Obituaries);Feeney, Charles F;Atlantic Philanthropies;Duty Free Shoppers Group
results.title: Charles Feeney, Who Made a Fortune and Then Gave It Away, Dies at 92
results.abstract: After piling up billions in business, he pledged to donate almost all of his money to causes before he died. He succeeded, and then lived a more modest life.

media.caption: Charles F. Feeney in 2012. In giving billions to a number of causes, he reversed an extravagant lifestyle, selling his limousines, flying coach and taking subways and cabs.

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Conservatism (US Politics);Scott, Austin (1969- );Jordan, Jim (1964- );Scalise, Steve;McCarthy, Kevin (1965- );Republican Party;House of Representatives
results.title: Republicans Tap Jordan for Speaker, but Delay Vote as Holdouts Balk
results.abstract: The Ohio congressman was his party’s second nominee this week to emerge from an internal fight. But with scores of Republicans refusing to back him, the party put off a House floor vote until next week.

media.caption: Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio renewed his bid for House speaker after Representative Steve Scalise of Louisiana was blocked from the job.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Writing and Writers;Poetry and Poets;Books and Literature;National Book Awards;Pulitzer Prizes;Nobel Prizes;Gluck, Louise
results.title: Louise Glück, Nobel-Winning Poet Who Explored Trauma and Loss, Dies at 80
results.abstract: Acclaimed as one of America’s greatest living writers, she blended deeply personal material with themes of mythology and nature.

media.caption: Louise Glück in 2012. Her work was both deeply personal — drawing, for example, on the pain she experienced at the death of her father — and broadly accessible, both to critics and the reading public.

results.title: Judy Chicago Makes ‘Herstory’: Beyond the Ladies of the Dinner Party
results.abstract: The pioneering feminist artist rules the New Museum with a six-decade survey, but she shares the stage with her sisterhood.

media.caption: The artist Judy Chicago in her studio in Belen, N.M., with her minimalist sculptures, “Moving Parts.” The anatomical shapes echo a feminist theme that still informs her practice today.
media.copyright: Gabriela Campos for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Interior Design and Furnishings;Walt Disney Company
results.title: It’s Not Enough to Love Disney. They Want to Live Disney.
results.abstract: For some, a dream is a wish your heart makes at home.

media.caption: Kelsey Hermanson in a “The Little Mermaid”-themed bathroom at her Seattle-area home. Each room in her 3,300-square-foot house has its own Disney-inspired theme. The company celebrates its 100th anniversary on Monday.
media.copyright: Meron Tekie Menghistab for The New York Times

results.title: One Officer Convicted and Another Acquitted in Elijah McClain Death
